comments_since_last_sample.body: I also add a little sign that has the Wi-Fi password.

Guests really enjoy the "Disaster Box", as well as the welcome basket. 
Our's contains a sewing kit with clear thread, needle already threaded, a lighter,  a rain poncho and a bus pass.

The Queen of Hotel and Hospitality!  I have been waiting for this!!!

Great info! Now please share what brands and styles in bed linens and towels. I love heavy damask type sheets or thick solids, but I'm having trouble locating any. Best (affordable) pillow brands maybe?
also wash the blankets, duvets and pillows.

Most important consideration for house guests: privacy - theirs and yours!  I have a guest bedroom on the same floor as the principal bedroom, and another on the ground floor.  Both have ensuites.  The guest room on the ground floor is adjacent to a reception room that includes a servery that offers a fridge, freezer (as drawers), microwave, dishwasher, and dishware and cutlery.  When guests are expected to stay there, I bring out the kettle, coffee maker and toaster.  I provide tea, coffee pods, bread, butter, jam, cheese, granola, some fresh fruit, orange juice, milk and cream, and, maybe, some fresh hard-boiled eggs.  That way, my guests don’t have to wait for me to feed them, and they can enjoy their breakfast in solitude in the reception room (with fireplace), or just outside the door on our covered patio, overlooking the back yard and pool.  There is even a stacked washer/dryer in a cabana bathroom on that floor for their use, if desired.  This alleviates the risk of  “too much togetherness” that often accompanies house guests.

The light switches....you are so right... I once had an encounter with a cactus in the dark in search of the door... 😂
And everybody hates to bother the host with all the stuff they forgot or suddenly need...I made a kind of a "rescue" basket in my bathroom for situations like that.
I always include a vase of fresh flowers on the night stand
Please, tips for focal point in room 😁
